Demonstrations Over George Floyd’s Death Spread Across U.S.Minnesota’s top officials acknowledged on Saturday morning that they had underestimated the protests. A curfew did little to stop the destruction.Gov. Tim Walz said that more National Guard troops would be deployed. Protesters also rallied in Atlanta, Los Angeles, Dallas and other cities.Earlier, a fired Minneapolis police officer who used his knee to pin down Mr. Floyd, a black man who later died, was charged with third-degree murder. Here’s the latest.
In Atlanta: Smashed Windows and Tense ClashesAt CNN headquarters, protesters seemed prepared to go inside during a face-off that was broadcast live on the cable network.
In New York: Thrown Bottles and Tear Gas“We don’t ever want to see another night like this,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said. Protesters clashed with the police across Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan.
Ex-Officer Charged in Death of George Floyd in MinneapolisThe former officer, Derek Chauvin, was taken into custody on charges that carry a combined maximum 35-year sentence.

What Happened in the Chaotic Moments Before George Floyd DiedThe episode began with a report of a counterfeit $20 bill. It ended in a fatal encounter, which the authorities have described in detail for the first time.

Twitter Had Been Drawing a Line for Months When Trump Crossed ItInside the company, one faction wanted Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief, to take a hard line against President Trump’s tweets while another urged him to remain hands-off.

While Twitter Confronts Trump, Mark Zuckerberg Keeps Facebook Out of ItThe companies have similar policies on the limits of what they allow users to post. But Facebook is more permissive when the user is President Trump.
Supreme Court, in 5-4 Decision, Rejects Church’s Challenge to Shutdown OrderA California church argued that restrictions on public gatherings were harder on houses of worship than on many businesses.

Rebuking China, Trump to Curtail Ties to Hong Kong and Sever Them With W.H.O.Critics say the actions would do little to blunt China’s influence and could ultimately hurt the U.S. and others.

‘Facing the Darkest Hour’: Hong Kong’s Protest Movement in CrisisAs the Chinese government’s grip tightens, demonstrators are debating how and why to keep fighting, or whether resistance is even possible.
Hong Kong officials reacted with a mix of anxiety, resignation and defiance to President Trump’s announcement.

A Mile-Long Line for Free Food in Geneva, One of World’s Richest CitiesThe Swiss city is best known for bankers, watchmakers and U.N. officials. But the virus has forced thousands from Geneva’s underclass to line up for hours for food aid.

In a German Restaurant, the Sommelier Lifts His Mask to Smell the WinePauly Saal, a Michelin-starred restaurant in Berlin, was one of the first restaurants in Europe to restart operations last week. How did it go?
Europe is gradually reopening. We’re driving more than 3,700 miles to document life on a changed continent.
